title: High Throughput Imaging and Analysis of Intracellular Dynamics with Correlative Label-Free and Fluorescence Microscopy
content: Dynamic correlative imaging is needed to understand the interactions among cells, organelles, and molecules which determine their functional state in health and disease. Common trade-offs in microscopy constrain the spatial resolution, temporal resolution, and number of channels that can be acquired from live biological samples before they degrade or change states. Correlative label-free and fluorescence microscopy relaxes some of these constraints as label-free imaging can report on the cell architecture and several landmark organelles, whereas fluorescence imaging can report on finer organelles and molecules. I will discuss two correlative imaging methods for high-content profiling of cells and molecules. miPolScope implements a broadband instant polarization-resolved detector for label-free imaging of the phase and orientation of biomolecules multiplexed with fluorescence imaging of protein localization and anisotropy [1]. Mantis combines remote-refocus label-free microscopy and oblique light-sheet fluorescence microscopy for fast and gentle imaging of multiple samples or biological perturbations [2]. We have developed open-source software for instrument calibration and real-time alignment, automated data acquisition, and distributed data reconstruction [3]. We have further optimized a deep-learning virtual staining pipeline for the prediction of cellular landmarks (e.g. nuclei and cell membrane) from label-free images to enable segmentation and single-cell analysis [4]. Overall, these tools enable scalable image-based longitudinal screens and dissection of specific biological responses to perturbation.
